results.title: The Art of action: martial arts at the movies
results.creator_credit: Columbia Tristar Home Entertainment, Joni Levin and Keith Clarke
results.brief_description: Samuel L Jackson presents and narrates an exploration of the origins of the martial arts genre - the pioneers of the movement, change makers throughout the decades, and those who carry on the legacy today. Originating in China in the mid 1700s when Shaolin monks instructed Peking Opera performers, the martial arts genre has become synonymous with action and drama that would later be injected with romance, humour and visual wizardry. The program is structured in a question and answer format and focuses on key performers, characters, and directors: Wong Fei Hung, Jackie Chan, Jet Li, Tsui Hark, Ang Lee, Sammo Hung, John Woo and Michelle Yeoh to name a few. It also looks at the prominent role of women in the genre, the contribution of the Shaw Brother’s company in the 1950s, the influence of Japanese cinema (in particular the work of Akira Kurosawa), American cinema, and the direction of martial arts films in the 21st Century. Boasting an abundance of film clips and interviews with (unfortunately unnamed by visual clues) practitioners of the trade, this DVD provides an excellent history of the genre.

results.title: The Arsenal stadium mystery
results.creator_credit: G&S Films, Josef Somlo and Thorold Dickinson
results.brief_description: Scotland Yard investigates when a caddish footballer dies by poisoning during a game between Arsenal and the Trojans. This fast-moving British thriller provides authentic footage of the pre-war Arsenal team training, playing and relaxing: from goalkeeper George Swindin to legendary winger Cliff ‘Boy’ Bastin. Genuine footage of a 1939 Arsenal match is intercut with re-staged close-up action. Stars Leslie Banks, Greta Gynt and the players and management of Arsenal Football Club 1939. From an original story by Leonard Reginald Gribble.

results.title: The Archive project
results.brief_description:
Melbourne documentary filmmaker John Hughes will join ACMI as artist in residence in order to produce an exhibition, DVD, book and film program dedicated to the work of the Melbourne Realist Film Unit. The exhibition is scheduled for September 2004. REVISED: The Archive Project will be exhibited as part of 2006 Contemporary Commonwealth.

People involved with the Realist Film Unit made twelve films between 1946 and 1951. Some of these are lost. Those saved are held by Screen Sound Australia. These projects have received some attention in unpublished theses. However, the important work of the Melbourne realists remains largely ‘hidden history’ to a wider public.

John Hughes and/or ACMI may draw further finance for the production of the work, through ACMI, or independently through JH from grants. JH in collaboration with ACMI will seek partnerships in the project. JH will work from ACMI at Federation Square and participate in ACMI’s activities. He will also act as a mentor for ACMI staff.

results.title: The Arab refugees
results.creator_credit: United Nations Television, Ben Park and Martin Bunnel
results.brief_description: 1.3 million Arab refugees now live in camps on both sides of the Jordan, in Gaza, and in neighbouring Arab lands. Since 1949 the U.N. relief agency has been working to provide emergency food and shelter, education and long term job training. But the presence of these proud, angry and uprooted people must continue to be an obstacle to peace - they are humans being denied fundamental rights.

results.title: The Apprentice
results.creator_credit: Fontana Films, Alan Harkness, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Malcolm Otton
results.brief_description: Answers the questions of potential apprentices and their parents about how the apprenticeship scheme works in Australian industry by concentrating on Robert, an apprentice fitter and turner with an automotive firm. Robert, his father and his supervisor give their views on the training involved, which is intended to develop a boy’s character as well as to produce a good craftsman.
